Monitization is the process by which central banks create money out of thin air. It is a way of increasing the supply of money in an economy, which can help to boost economic activity. However, monitisation can also have negative consequences, such as inflating asset prices and creating bubbles. Indian economy is facing a major challenge. The Indian government is trying to boost the economy by increasing investment.
The government has introduced a number of policies to attract foreign investors. One of the most important policies is the Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) policy. This policy allows foreign companies to invest in India without having to set up a local company. However, the FDI policy also has some restrictions. For example, foreign firms are not allowed to own more than 49% of an Indian company’s equity. In addition, they are only allowed 100% foreign ownership in certain sectors such as pharmaceuticals, telecommunications, and infrastructure. These restrictions make it difficult for foreign businesses to enter the Indian market. As a result, many foreigners have chosen to leave India rather than face these restrictions and compete against local companies.

Indian economy has been growing at a faster rate than the rest of the world, but the pace of growth has slowed down in the last few years. The reason for this slowdown is the declining rate of productivity growth.
Productivity is a measure of output per unit of input. It is one of those factors which determine the growth rate and standard of living of a country. If a worker produces more output with the same level of inputs, it means that productive efficiency has increased. This means higher incomes for the workers and higher profits for businesses. Thus, productivities growth is an important factor in determining the rate at which an economy grows. The government’s decision to devalue the rupee by 12% has had a positive effect on exports, as it has made Indian goods more competitive in the international market. How does the Indian Economy work?
The Indian economic system is based on the principles of mixed economics. In this system, the role of government and private sector is balanced. There is no single dominant sector in this economy. Private sector plays an important role and contributes to the Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
Government is responsible for the overall development of economy and it is also responsible to provide basic amenities to its citizens. This includes health, education, sanitation, housing and

Indian economy: the state of play
India is a key player in the global economy. Its economic growth is expected to slow down in 2018, but the country remains a bright spot in a world of slowing growth.
The country’s growth slowed down to 6.3% in Q1 17 from 7.1% a year ago. It was the slowest growth rate in three years. The slowdown was largely due to a decline in private consumption and investments. Investments fell by 3.4% from a 9.5% growth in April-June 0216, while private consumer spending fell 4.2% y-o-y in July-September 51. This is the first time in two years that the private investment and private spends have contracted in India. India’ s GDP growth

Indian economy is going through a tough time. It is facing the brunt of the global economic slowdown. The slow down in the Indian growth rate has been attributed to the poor performance of agriculture, manufacturing and services. In the agricultural sector, the growth of output has slowed down due to inadequate monsoon rains.
The growth in manufacture sector has come down to 7.9% in 2012-13 from 10.2% a year ago. This is due mainly to a slowing down of investment and exports. Services sector too has not been spared by the slow-down in growth. Due to lower demand, there has also been a fall in industrial production and retail sales. Indian economy: Sustaining the growth momentum
India’s economy has been on a high growth trajectory in recent years. The country has achieved this by focusing on key structural reforms, including the introduction of the Goods and Services Tax (GST), the implementation of demonetisation and the recapitalisation of state-owned banks.
These revenue-raising measures have helped to reduce the fiscal deficit and increase the government’ssavings. In addition, the Indian government has made significant progress in reducing its debt burden. As a result, India’stotal debts as a percentage of GDP have declined from 94.2% in 2012 to 82.1% today. This has helped India to maintain its AAA credit rating. However, there are some challenges that India faces in terms of sustaining its growth rate

Indian economy is the world's fastest growing major economy. India is an emerging market with 1.2 billion people. It is one of the most attractive markets for foreign investment. The country is ranked 6th in the World Bank' s Ease of Doing Business Index.
The country has a robust and flexible legal system, which is based on the British common law system and the Indian Contract Act, 2002. There is no minimum capital requirement for setting up a company in India. However, a minimum paid up capital is required for the issue of shares. Investment in a private limited company can be made either through the FDI route or the automatic route. Fresh investments in an existing private company are permitted through both the routes.
